questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding a developing erythroblast?

options.label: A
options.text: Has the highest number of transferrin receptors

options.label: B
options.text: Produces ERFE which stimulates hepcidin production

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

questions.correct_answer: A. Has the highest number of transferrin receptors
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Has the highest number of transferrin receptors Option A - The transferrin receptors are found on cells in many tissues within the body and all cells at some time during development will display transferrin receptors— the cell having the greatest number of receptors (300,000- 400,000/cell) is the developing erythroblast.

Highyeild:

Iron homeostasis is regulated by Hepcidin which degrades Ferroportin and decreases iron absorption. Hepcidin also blocks the release of iron from macrophages which is an important source of iron in erythropoiesis. Decrease in hepcidin levels will increase ferroportin expression thereby increasing iron absorption. This iron will be taken up by carrier protein transferrin which delivers the iron to the cells with transferrin receptors like hepatocytes and developing erythroblast in bone marrow.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B – A developing erythroblast produces ERFE (Erythroferrone) which suppresses hepcidin there by leading to increased iron absorption.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding iron transport when the iron-bearing transferrin interacts with its receptor?

options.label: A
options.text: The complex is Internalized via clathrin-coated pits

options.label: B
options.text: Transported to an acidic endosome

options.label: C
options.text: The iron is released at the low pH

options.label: D
options.text: Bulk of transferrin receptor is released back into circulation

questions.correct_answer: D. Bulk of transferrin receptor is released back into circulation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bulk of transferrin receptor is released back into circulation Once the iron-bearing transferrin interacts with its receptor, the complex is internalized via clathrin-coated pits and transported to an acidic endosome , where the iron is released at the low ph. The iron is then made available for heme synthesis while the transferrin-receptor complex is recycled to the surface of the cell. where the bulk of the transferrin is released back into circulation and the transferrin receptor re-anchors into the cell membrane.

Highyeild:

A certain amount of the transferrin receptor protein may be released into circulation and can be measured as soluble transferrin receptor protein (sTfR). It is the circulating protein derived from cleavage of the membrane transferrin receptor on erythroid precursor cells in the bone marrow The soluble transferrin receptor (sTfR) can be used to identify concomitant iron deficiency in the setting of ACD/AI (Anemia of chronic disease / Anemia of chronic inflammation). In iron deficiency, Transferrin receptor density increases on cell membranes, and truncated sTfR increases in the serum. In contrast, in ACD/AI, cytokines suppress the expression of Transferrin receptors. Thus, the concentration of sTfR varies in a similar pattern to transferrin and remains normal in ACD/AI).

questions.text: Regarding the absorption of iron from diet, which of the following is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: Maximum absorption occurs in the Ileum

options.label: B
options.text: The ferric iron is converted to the ferrous form by a ferri reductase

options.label: C
options.text: Acidic pH of the environment

options.label: D
options.text: Transport across the membrane is accomplished by Nramp 2

questions.correct_answer: A. Maximum absorption occurs in the Ileum
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Maximum absorption occurs in the Ileum Iron absorption takes place largely in the duodenum and proximal jejunum. At the brush border of the absorptive cell, the ferric iron is converted to the ferrous form by a ferri reductase For absorption, iron must be taken up by the luminal cell. That process is facilitated by the acidic contents of the stomach, which maintains the iron in solution Transport across the membrane is accomplished by divalent metal transporter type 1 (DMT-1, also known as natural resistance macrophage-associated protein type 2 [Nramp 2] or DCT-1)

Extraedge:

DMT-1 also facilitates uptake of other trace metals like Manganese, copper, zinc and cobalt which are essential for the body. Iron within the enterocyte is released into the blood via ferroportin. And this iron is picked up by transport glycoprotein called transferrin. Both DMT-1 and ferroportin are found in cells involved in iron transport (e.g. macrophages) .

questions.text: Which of the following transporters is responsible for transport of iron in the gut across the membrane?

options.label: A
options.text: Divalent metal transporter type 1 (DMT-1)

options.label: B
options.text: Natural resistance macrophage-associated protein type 2 [Nramp 2]

options.label: C
options.text: DCT-1

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Transport across the membrane is accomplished by divalent metal transporter type 1 (DMT-1, also known as natural resistance macrophage-associated protein type 2 [Nramp 2] or DCT-1). DMT-1 is a general cation transporter.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, B, C: All names refer to the same transporter.

questions.text: Iron absorption is predominantly regulated at the basolateral surface of the duodenal enterocyte by control of iron export through a membrane embedded iron exporter into plasma. In this regard which of the following is NOT true of hepcidin?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the principal iron regulatory hormone

options.label: B
options.text: Negatively regulates the function of that iron exporter

options.label: C
options.text: Negatively regulated by ERFE

options.label: D
options.text: Increased level in increased ineffective erythropoiesis

questions.correct_answer: D. Increased level in increased ineffective erythropoiesis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased level in increased ineffective erythropoiesis Once inside the gut cell, iron may be stored as ferritin or transported through the cell to be released at the basolateral surface to plasma transferrin through the membrane-embedded iron exporter, ferroportin. The function of ferroportin is negatively regulated by hepcidin , the principal iron regulatory hormone. Patients with anemias associated with high levels of ineffective erythropoiesis absorb excess amounts of dietary iron. The molecular mechanism underlying this is the production of erythroferrone (ERFE) by developing erythroblasts. ERFE suppresses hepcidin production, increases iron absorption and over time, this may lead to iron overload and tissue damage.

Extraedge:

Absorbed iron is transported across basolateral membrane and this transport requires ferroportin and hephaestin to convert ferrous to ferric form. Mucosal ferritin within the cell is usually lost during normal sloughing of epithelium. Decrease in hepcidin levels will increase ferroportin expression and thereby increase iron absorption,

questions.text: A 58 year old lady who achieved menopause 3 years back, now presented with anemia likely due to deficiency of iron. The etiology more likely to be considered here would be?

options.label: A
options.text: Dietary deficiency

options.label: B
options.text: Malabsorption

options.label: C
options.text: Gastrointestinal blood loss

options.label: D
options.text: Physiological

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gastrointestinal blood loss A cardinal rule is that the appearance of iron deficiency in an adult male or post-menopausal female means gastrointestinal blood loss until proven otherwise.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, B: Relatively less common causes. Option: D: Not justifiable

Extraedge:

If iron deficiency is diagnosed and an obvious cause is not identified, additional testing for possible occult gastrointestinal blood loss (eg,with endoscopy or colonoscopy) is indicated for adults of all ages for whom a source of bleeding would be treated. A negative history of blood in the stool or negative fecal occult blood testing cannot be used to eliminate the possibility of a gastrointestinal source of bleeding, since bleeding may be intermittent and/or too small of an amount to turn the stool dark.

questions.text: Cheilosis (fissures at the corners of the mouth) and koilonychia (spooning of the fingernails) in a patient would be more likely Not be associated with which of the following findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Marrow examination revealing erythroid hyperplasia

options.label: B
options.text: Target cells and poikilocytes appear on the blood smear as cigar- or pencil-shaped forms.

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased prominence of microcytosis and hypochromicity on smear,

options.label: D
options.text: All the above

questions.correct_answer: C. Decreased prominence of microcytosis and hypochromicity on smear,
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decreased prominence of microcytosis and hypochromicity on smear, Signs related to iron deficiency depend on the severity and chronicity of the anemia in addition to the usual signs of anemia—fatigue, pallor, and reduced exercise capacity. With advanced iron deficiency, resulting in more severe anemia (hemoglobin 7–8 g/dL), hypochromia and microcytosis become more prominent. Target cells and misshapen red cells (poikilocytes) appear on the blood smear as cigar- or pencil-shaped forms, and the erythroid marrow becomes increasingly ineffective. Consequently, with severe prolonged iron-deficiency anemia, erythroid hyperplasia of the marrow develops, rather than hypoproliferation. Cheilosis (fissures at the corners of the mouth) and koilonychia (spooning of the fingernails) are signs of advanced tissue iron deficiency Koilonychia (spooning of the fingernails) are signs of advanced tissue iron deficiency.

questions.text: A serum iron test measures how much iron is in your blood. All of the following are true about serum iron assessment EXCEPT?

options.label: A
options.text: Iron-deficiency states are associated with saturation levels < 20%

options.label: B
options.text: There is no diurnal variation in the serum iron

options.label: C
options.text: A transferrin saturation >50% indicates that a disproportionate amount of the iron bound to transferrin is being delivered to non erythroid tissues

options.label: D
options.text: A transferrin saturation >50% may lead to tissue iron overload ove

questions.correct_answer: B. There is no diurnal variation in the serum iron
questions.explanation:
Solution:

There is no diurnal variation in the serum iron There is a diurnal variation in the serum iron.

Highyeild:

The serum iron level represents the amount of circulating iron bound to transferrin. The TIBC is an indirect measure of the circulating transferrin. The normal range for the serum iron is 50–150 μg/dL ; the normal range for TIBC is 300–360 μg/dL . Transferrin saturation, which is normally 25–50%, is obtained by the following formula: serum iron × 100 ÷ TIBC.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option C - A transferrin saturation >50% indicates that a disproportionate amount of the iron bound to transferrin is being delivered to non erythroid tissues. \ Option D - If this persists for an extended time , tissue iron overload may occur. Option A – True

questions.text: Free iron is toxic to cells, and the body has established an elaborate set of protective mechanisms to bind iron in various tissue compartments. Which of the following is true about it?

options.label: A
options.text: Apoferritin binds to free ferrous iron and stores it in the same state

options.label: B
options.text: Apoferritin binds to free ferric iron and stores it in the same state

options.label: C
options.text: Apoferritin binds to free ferrous iron and stores it in the ferric state

options.label: D
options.text: Apoferritin binds to free ferric iron and stores it in the ferrous state

questions.correct_answer: C. Apoferritin binds to free ferrous iron and stores it in the ferric state
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Apoferritin binds to free ferrous iron and stores it in the ferric state Within cells, iron is stored Complexed to protein as ferritin or hemosiderin. Apoferritin binds to free ferrous iron and stores it in the ferric state. As ferritin accumulates within cells of the RE system, protein aggregates are formed as hemosiderin.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Stores it in the ferric state. Option: B, D: Apoferritin binds to free ferrous iron.

questions.text: Which of the following provides information about the effective delivery of iron to developing erythroblasts?

options.label: A
options.text: Marrow iron stain

options.label: B
options.text: Serum ferritin

options.label: C
options.text: Tissue hemosiderin

options.label: D
options.text: Hepcidin

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Marrow iron stain In addition to correlating with storage iron, the marrow iron stain also provides information about the effective delivery of iron to developing erythroblasts. The serum ferritin level is a better indicator of iron overload than the marrow iron stain. Iron in ferritin or hemosiderin can be extracted for release by the RE cells, although hemosiderin is less readily available.

questions.text: A 46 year aged lady present with fatigue, generalized weakness and swelling of both feet for the last few months. She underwent investigations that showed increased red cell protoporphyrin levels. Which of the following could be true of her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Microcytic hypochromic anemia

options.label: B
options.text: Patient finding difficulty in lifting pen while writing

options.label: C
options.text: Increased serum levels of soluble transferrin receptor protein in blood

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above A – Seen in both iron deficiency and lead toxicity B – Symptom of lead toxicity in the form of wrist / finger drop C- suggestive of iron deficiency Protoporphyrin is an intermediate in the pathway to heme synthesis. When heme synthesis is impaired, protoporphyrin accumulates within the red cell. This denotes that there is an inadequate supply of iron to erythroid precursors to support hemoglobin synthesis. Normal values are less than 30 μg/dL. The most common causes of increased red cell protoporphyrin levels are absolute or relative iron deficiency and lead poisoning and values are usually more than 100 μg/dL

questions.text: A 32 year aged lady presented to your OPD with reports suggestive of iron deficiency anemia. You prescribe her a course of oral iron therapy. Which of the following would be false for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: A dose of 200 mg of elemental iron per day should result in the absorption of iron up to 50 mg/d

options.label: B
options.text: Gastrointestinal side effects are a major impediment to the effective treatment

options.label: C
options.text: Reticulocyte levels peak around 3 to 4 days after initiating iron therapy

options.label: D
options.text: The absence of response to therapy may be due to a confounding diagnosis

questions.correct_answer: C. Reticulocyte levels peak around 3 to 4 days after initiating iron therapy
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reticulocyte levels peak around 3 to 4 days after initiating iron therapy. The response to iron therapy varies, depending on the erythropoietin stimulus and the rate of absorption. Typically, the reticulocyte count begins to increase within 4–7 days after initiation of therapy but it peaks at around 1–1½ weeks. Oral iron preparations should be taken on an empty stomach, since food may inhibit iron absorption. Iron replacement therapy, up to 200 mg of elemental iron per day is given, This supports a red cell production level of two to three times normal in an individual with a normally functioning marrow and appropriate erythropoietin (EPO) stimulus. Of the complications of oral iron therapy, gastrointestinal distress is the most prominent and is seen in at least 15–20% of patients in the form of abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or constipation. The absence of a response may be due to poor absorption, noncompliance or a confounding diagnosis.

questions.text: A 28 year aged lady is on oral iron therapy. The reticulocyte level doesn’t increase even on 10th day, showing absence of response to iron therapy. What can be the cause?

options.label: A
options.text: Poor absorption

options.label: B
options.text: Noncompliance

options.label: C
options.text: Confounding diagnosis

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above The absence of a response may be due to poor absorption, noncompliance (which is common), or a confounding diagnosis. Amongst the diet, vegetarian diet contains phytates and phosphates which interfere with iron and decrease its absorption. Gastrointestinal side effects are a major impediment to the effective treatment. Small doses of iron or iron preparations with delayed release may help some of the patients in this regard. The response to iron therapy varies, depending on the EPO stimulus and the rate of absorption.

Highyeild:

questions.text: Which of the following is FALSE about the iron tolerance test?

options.label: A
options.text: One can determine the patient’s ability to absorb iron from the GI tract

options.label: B
options.text: Two iron tablets are given to the patient with meals

options.label: C
options.text: Monitoring of serum iron serially over the subsequent 2–3 h is mandatory

options.label: D
options.text: In the presence of normal absorption from GIT, there in an increase in the serum iron of at least 100 μg/dL

questions.correct_answer: B. Two iron tablets are given to the patient with meals
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Two iron tablets are given to the patient with meals. Iron tolerance test is quite useful in the clinic to determine the patient’s ability to absorb iron. Two iron tablets are given to the patient on an empty stomach, and the serum iron is measured serially over the subsequent 2–3 h. Oral iron preparations should be taken on an empty stomach, since food may inhibit iron absorption Normal absorption will result in an increase in the serum iron of at least 100 μg/dL.

Highyeild:

Factors influencing the absorption and bioavailability of dietary iron ' Absorption of heme iron Amount of heme iron, especially in meat Absorption of nonheme iron Iron status Amount of potentially available nonheme iron Balance between positive and negative factors Positive factors Meat or fish (factors in meat other than heme iron enhance absorption of nonheme iron) Negative factors Certain medications, such as proton pump inhibitors Phytate (in bran, oats, rye fiber) Polyphenols (in tea, some vegetables and cereals) Soy protein
